title: Why being average is sometimes better.
excerpt: Being average can offer the best of both worlds—learning from high achievers while supporting those who struggle, all while growing through failure.
paragraphs: Greetings dear friends! Today I'll be speaking on the topic 'Why being average is sometimes better.'
A person who is average, gets to live the best of both worlds. For instance, I am an average student.

Let’s say in my class, there are two groups of people. There’s a first group of students who are struggling in their academics; and then there is a second group of students who perform well in their academics.
I can receive help from the students who perform better since I have an urge to learn.
And I can also help the students who are struggling because I know what it feels like to be struggling myself.
I can group myself into both these groups of people.
Being average is like a bucket half full. I already acquire enough water to quench my thirst; but I also have enough space, to fill myself with more water and with more knowledge.
I am not to be mistaken with a student who is very high achieving just because I have the urge to learn.
Why? Because I can fail. And honestly speaking, I have the habit of failing.
This gives me the scope to rise up faster from my falls.
This gives me the scope to try, fail, try again, and maybe, in the end, succeed.
Dear friends, my name is Srija Bhaduri, and this was the speech of a very average student.

images.caption: Why being average is sometimes better: finding growth, balance, and resilience in everyday learning.
